<div class="byline">
<p class="author-name" data-aid="159162948" id="author1">By Elder Gerrit W. Gong</p>
<p class="author-role" data-aid="159162952" id="author2">Of the Quorum of the Twelve Apostles</p>

<p class="kicker" data-aid="159162956" id="kicker1">In time and eternity, the purpose of Creation and the nature of God Himself are to bring all things together for our good.</p>
</header>
<div class="body-block">
<p data-aid="159162961" id="p1">Today is April 6, the anniversary of Jesus Christ restoring His latter-day Church—and part of the Easter season, when we joyfully testify of Jesus Christ’s perfect life, atoning sacrifice, and glorious Resurrection.</p>
<p data-aid="159162972" id="p2">A Chinese story begins as a man’s son finds a beautiful horse.</p>
<p data-aid="159162978" id="p3">“How fortunate,” the neighbors say.</p>
<p data-aid="159162984" id="p4">“We’ll see,” says the man.</p>
<p data-aid="159162990" id="p5">Then the son falls off the horse and is permanently injured.</p>
<p data-aid="159162996" id="p6">“How unfortunate,” the neighbors say.</p>
<p data-aid="159163002" id="p7">“We’ll see,” says the man.</p>
<p data-aid="159163007" id="p8">A conscripting army comes but doesn’t take the injured son.</p>
<p data-aid="159163012" id="p9">“How fortunate,” the neighbors say.</p>
<p data-aid="159163019" id="p10">“We’ll see,” says the man.</p>
<p data-aid="159163024" id="p11">This fickle world often feels tempest tossed, uncertain, sometimes fortunate, and—too often—unfortunate. Yet, in this world of tribulation,<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note1" data-scroll-id="note1"><sup class="marker" data-value="1"></sup></a> “we know that all things work together for good to them that love God.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note2" data-scroll-id="note2"><sup class="marker" data-value="2"></sup></a> Indeed, as we walk uprightly and remember our covenants, “all things shall work together for your good.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note3" data-scroll-id="note3"><sup class="marker" data-value="3"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163028" id="p12">All things for our good.</p>
<p data-aid="159163034" id="p13">A remarkable promise! Comforting assurance from God Himself! In a miraculous way, the purpose of Creation and the nature of God are to know beginning and end,<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note4" data-scroll-id="note4"><sup class="marker" data-value="4"></sup></a> to bring about all that is for our good, and to help us become sanctified and holy through Jesus Christ’s grace and Atonement.</p>
<p data-aid="159163040" id="p14">Jesus Christ’s Atonement can deliver and redeem us from sin. But Jesus Christ also intimately understands our every pain, affliction, sickness,<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note5" data-scroll-id="note5"><sup class="marker" data-value="5"></sup></a> sorrow, separation. In time and eternity, His triumph over death and hell can make all things right.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note6" data-scroll-id="note6"><sup class="marker" data-value="6"></sup></a> He helps heal the broken and disparaged, reconcile the angry and divided, comfort the lonely and isolated, encourage the uncertain and imperfect, and bring forth miracles possible only with God.</p>
<p data-aid="159163045" id="p15">We sing hallelujah and shout hosanna! With eternal power and infinite goodness, in God’s plan of happiness all things can work together for our good. We can face life with confidence and not fear.</p>
<p data-aid="159163051" id="p16">Left on our own, we may not know our own good. When “I choose me,” I am also choosing my own limitations, weaknesses, inadequacies. Ultimately, to do the most good, we must be good.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note7" data-scroll-id="note7"><sup class="marker" data-value="7"></sup></a> Since none save God is good,<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note8" data-scroll-id="note8"><sup class="marker" data-value="8"></sup></a> we seek perfection in Jesus Christ.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note9" data-scroll-id="note9"><sup class="marker" data-value="9"></sup></a> We become our truest, best selves only as we put off the natural man or woman and become a child before God.</p>
<p data-aid="159163055" id="p17">With our trust and faith in God, trials and afflictions can be consecrated <span class="page-break" data-page="42"></span>for our good. Joseph, sold into slavery in Egypt, later saved his family and people. The Prophet Joseph Smith’s incarceration in Liberty Jail taught him “these things shall give thee experience, and shall be for thy good.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note10" data-scroll-id="note10"><sup class="marker" data-value="10"></sup></a> Lived with faith, trials and sacrifices we would never choose can bless us and others in ways never imagined.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note11" data-scroll-id="note11"><sup class="marker" data-value="11"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163060" id="p18">We increase faith and trust in the Lord that all things can work together for our good as we gain eternal perspective;<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note12" data-scroll-id="note12"><sup class="marker" data-value="12"></sup></a> understand our trials may be “but for a small moment”;<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note13" data-scroll-id="note13"><sup class="marker" data-value="13"></sup></a> recognize affliction can be consecrated for our gain;<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note14" data-scroll-id="note14"><sup class="marker" data-value="14"></sup></a> acknowledge accidents, untimely death, debilitating illness, and disease are part of mortality; and trust loving Heavenly Father does not give trials to punish or judge. He would not give a stone to someone asking for bread nor a serpent to one asking for a fish.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note15" data-scroll-id="note15"><sup class="marker" data-value="15"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163066" id="p19">When trials come, often what we most want is for someone to listen and be with us.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note16" data-scroll-id="note16"><sup class="marker" data-value="16"></sup></a> In the moment, cliché answers can be unhelpful, however comforting their intent. Sometimes we yearn for someone who will grieve, ache, and weep with us; let us express pain, frustration, sometimes even anger; and acknowledge with us there are things we do not know.</p>
<p data-aid="159163075" id="p20">When we trust God and His love for us, even our greatest heartbreaks can, in the end, work together for our good.</p>
<p data-aid="159163081" id="p21">I remember the day I received word of a serious car accident which involved those I love. At such times, in anguish and faith, we can only say with Job, “The Lord gave, and the Lord hath taken away; blessed be the name of the Lord.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note17" data-scroll-id="note17"><sup class="marker" data-value="17"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163086" id="p22">Across the worldwide Church, some 3,500 stakes and districts and some 30,000 wards and branches provide refuge and safety.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note18" data-scroll-id="note18"><sup class="marker" data-value="18"></sup></a> But within our stakes and wards, many faithful families and individuals confront difficult challenges, even while knowing that (without yet knowing how) things will work together for our good.</p>
<p data-aid="159163093" id="p23">In Huddersfield, England, Brother Samuel Bridgstock was diagnosed with stage-four cancer shortly before the calling of a new stake president. Given his dire diagnosis, he asked his wife, Anna, why he would even go to be interviewed.</p>
<p data-aid="159163098" id="p24">“Because,” Sister Bridgstock said, “you’re going to be called as stake president.”</p>
<div><div class="imageWrapper-wTPPD"><figure class="imageWithModal-ILaMF loadImageItem-u5D4D" title="Bridgstock family."><img width="500" height="374" alt=""/><div class="container-W4jed"><div class="innerFlex-R9N_u"><svg viewBox="0 0 24 24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="presentation" class="sc-1d18oav-0 bYvpFK"> <path fill="currentColor" d="M20 4.75L19.25 4v16l.75-.75H4l.75.75V4L4 4.75h16zM3.25 4v16c0 .414.336.75.75.75h16a.75.75 0 0 0 .75-.75V4a.75.75 0 0 0-.75-.75H4a.75.75 0 0 0-.75.75zm11.07 8.888c.23-.357.606-.353.828-.008l2.887 4.482c.227.352.06.638-.357.638H6.326c-.421 0-.581-.3-.37-.648l4.006-6.622c.217-.358.567-.359.793.014l2.396 3.96 1.17-1.816zm1.59-2.735c1.14 0 2.066-.907 2.066-2.026 0-1.12-.926-2.027-2.067-2.027s-2.066.907-2.066 2.027c0 1.119.925 2.026 2.066 2.026z"> </path></svg><div class="description-Rip0y"><div class="sc-1szn76m-0 cRcVWO i18nString-raclU">Image</div><div class="sc-1szn76m-0 cRcVWO title-RrK9J">Bridgstock family.</div></div></div></div></figure></div></div>
<p data-aid="159163102" id="p25">Initially given a year or two to live, President Bridgstock (who is here today) is now in his fourth year of service. He has good and hard days. His stake is rallying with increased faith, service, and kindness. It is not easy, but his wife and family live with faith, gratitude, and understandable sadness they trust will become eternal joy through Jesus Christ’s restoring Atonement.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note19" data-scroll-id="note19"><sup class="marker" data-value="19"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163107" id="p26">When we are still, open, and reverent, we may feel the beauty, purpose, and serenity of the covenant belonging the Lord offers. In sacred moments, He may let us glimpse the larger eternal reality of which our daily lives are part, where small and simple things work together for the good of givers and receivers.</p>
<p data-aid="159163112" id="p27">Rebekah, the daughter of my first mission president, shared how the Lord answered her prayer for comfort with an unexpected opportunity to answer someone else’s prayer.</p>
<div><div class="imageWrapper-wTPPD"><figure class="imageWithModal-ILaMF loadImageItem-u5D4D" title="Rebekah gave the woman her mother’s oxygen machine."><img width="500" height="281" alt=""/><div class="container-W4jed"><div class="innerFlex-R9N_u"><svg viewBox="0 0 24 24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="presentation" class="sc-1d18oav-0 bYvpFK"> <path fill="currentColor" d="M20 4.75L19.25 4v16l.75-.75H4l.75.75V4L4 4.75h16zM3.25 4v16c0 .414.336.75.75.75h16a.75.75 0 0 0 .75-.75V4a.75.75 0 0 0-.75-.75H4a.75.75 0 0 0-.75.75zm11.07 8.888c.23-.357.606-.353.828-.008l2.887 4.482c.227.352.06.638-.357.638H6.326c-.421 0-.581-.3-.37-.648l4.006-6.622c.217-.358.567-.359.793.014l2.396 3.96 1.17-1.816zm1.59-2.735c1.14 0 2.066-.907 2.066-2.026 0-1.12-.926-2.027-2.067-2.027s-2.066.907-2.066 2.027c0 1.119.925 2.026 2.066 2.026z"> </path></svg><div class="description-Rip0y"><div class="sc-1szn76m-0 cRcVWO i18nString-raclU">Image</div><div class="sc-1szn76m-0 cRcVWO title-RrK9J">Rebekah gave the woman her mother’s oxygen machine.</div></div></div></div></figure></div></div>
<p data-aid="159163117" id="p28">Late one evening, Rebekah, grieving her mother’s recent passing, had a clear impression to go buy gas for her car. When she arrived at the station, she met an elderly woman struggling <span class="page-break" data-page="43"></span>to breathe with a large oxygen tank. Later, Rebekah was able to give the woman her mother’s portable oxygen machine. This sister gratefully said, “You’ve given me back my freedom.” Things work together for good when we minister as Jesus Christ would.</p>
<p data-aid="159163121" id="p29">A father assigned with his teacher-age son as ministering companions explained, “Ministering is when we go from being neighbors who bring cookies to trusted friends, spiritual first responders.” Covenant belonging in Jesus Christ comforts, connects, consecrates.</p>
<p data-aid="159163125" id="p30">Even in tragedy, spiritual preparation may remind us Heavenly Father knew when we felt most vulnerable and alone. For example, a family whose child was taken to the hospital later found comfort in remembering the Holy Ghost had whispered in advance what to expect.</p>
<p data-aid="159163130" id="p31">Sometimes the larger eternal reality the Lord lets us feel includes family across the veil. A sister found joy in conversion to Jesus Christ’s restored gospel. Yet two traumas had deeply impacted her life—seeing a boating accident and tragically losing her mother, who had taken her own life.</p>
<div><div class="imageWrapper-wTPPD"><figure class="imageWithModal-ILaMF loadImageItem-u5D4D" title="Sister overcame her fear and was baptized."><img width="500" height="374" alt=""/><div class="container-W4jed"><div class="innerFlex-R9N_u"><svg viewBox="0 0 24 24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="presentation" class="sc-1d18oav-0 bYvpFK"> <path fill="currentColor" d="M20 4.75L19.25 4v16l.75-.75H4l.75.75V4L4 4.75h16zM3.25 4v16c0 .414.336.75.75.75h16a.75.75 0 0 0 .75-.75V4a.75.75 0 0 0-.75-.75H4a.75.75 0 0 0-.75.75zm11.07 8.888c.23-.357.606-.353.828-.008l2.887 4.482c.227.352.06.638-.357.638H6.326c-.421 0-.581-.3-.37-.648l4.006-6.622c.217-.358.567-.359.793.014l2.396 3.96 1.17-1.816zm1.59-2.735c1.14 0 2.066-.907 2.066-2.026 0-1.12-.926-2.027-2.067-2.027s-2.066.907-2.066 2.027c0 1.119.925 2.026 2.066 2.026z"> </path></svg><div class="description-Rip0y"><div class="sc-1szn76m-0 cRcVWO i18nString-raclU">Image</div><div class="sc-1szn76m-0 cRcVWO title-RrK9J">Sister overcame her fear and was baptized.</div></div></div></div></figure></div></div>
<p data-aid="159163135" id="p32">Yet this sister overcame her fear of water enough to be baptized by immersion. And on what became a very happy day, she witnessed someone, acting as proxy for her deceased mother, be baptized in the temple. “Temple baptism healed my mother, and it freed me,” the sister said. “It was the first time I felt peace since my mother died.”</p>
<p data-aid="159163140" id="p33">Our sacred music echoes His assurance that all things can work together for our good.</p>
<div class="poetry">
<div class="stanza">
<p class="line" data-aid="159163146" id="p34">Be still, my soul: Thy God doth undertake</p>
<p class="line" data-aid="159163152" id="p35">To guide the future as he has the past.</p>
<p class="line" data-aid="159163159" id="p36">Thy hope, thy confidence let nothing shake;</p>
<p class="line" data-aid="159163165" id="p37">All now mysterious shall be bright at last.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note20" data-scroll-id="note20"><sup class="marker" data-value="20"></sup></a></p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="poetry">
<div class="stanza">
<p class="line" data-aid="159163172" id="p38">Come, come, ye Saints, no toil nor labor fear;</p>
<p class="line" data-aid="159163179" id="p39">But with joy wend your way.</p>
<p class="line" data-aid="159163186" id="p40">Though hard to you this journey may appear,</p>
<p class="line" data-aid="159163192" id="p41">Grace shall be as your day. …</p>
<p class="line" data-aid="159163199" id="p42">And should we die before our journey’s through,</p>
<p class="line" data-aid="159163204" id="p43">Happy day! All is well!<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note21" data-scroll-id="note21"><sup class="marker" data-value="21"></sup></a></p>
</div>
</div>
<p data-aid="159163211" id="p44">The Book of Mormon is evidence we can hold in our hand that Jesus is the Christ and God fulfills His prophecies. Written by inspired prophets who saw our day, the Book of Mormon begins with raw drama—a family dealing with deep differences. Yet, as we study and ponder 1 Nephi 1 through to Moroni 10, we are drawn to Jesus Christ with a firm testimony that what happened there and then can bless us here and now.</p>
<p data-aid="159163218" id="p45">As the Lord, through His living prophet, brings more houses of the Lord closer in more places, temple blessings work together for our good. We come by covenant and ordinance to God our Father and Jesus Christ and gain eternal perspective on mortality. One by one, name by name, we offer beloved family members—ancestors—sacred ordinances and covenant blessings in the Lord’s pattern of saviors on Mount Zion.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note22" data-scroll-id="note22"><sup class="marker" data-value="22"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163225" id="p46">As temples come closer to us in many places, a temple sacrifice we can offer is to seek holiness in the house of the Lord more frequently. For many years, we have saved, planned, and sacrificed to come to the temple. Now, as circumstances permit, please come even more often to the Lord in His holy house. Let regular temple worship and service bless, protect, and inspire you and your family—the family you have or the family you will have and become someday.</p>
<div><div class="imageWrapper-wTPPD"><figure class="imageWithModal-ILaMF loadImageItem-u5D4D" title="Grandmother outside the temple."><img width="500" height="374" alt=""/><div class="container-W4jed"><div class="innerFlex-R9N_u"><svg viewBox="0 0 24 24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="presentation" class="sc-1d18oav-0 bYvpFK"> <path fill="currentColor" d="M20 4.75L19.25 4v16l.75-.75H4l.75.75V4L4 4.75h16zM3.25 4v16c0 .414.336.75.75.75h16a.75.75 0 0 0 .75-.75V4a.75.75 0 0 0-.75-.75H4a.75.75 0 0 0-.75.75zm11.07 8.888c.23-.357.606-.353.828-.008l2.887 4.482c.227.352.06.638-.357.638H6.326c-.421 0-.581-.3-.37-.648l4.006-6.622c.217-.358.567-.359.793.014l2.396 3.96 1.17-1.816zm1.59-2.735c1.14 0 2.066-.907 2.066-2.026 0-1.12-.926-2.027-2.067-2.027s-2.066.907-2.066 2.027c0 1.119.925 2.026 2.066 2.026z"> </path></svg><div class="description-Rip0y"><div class="sc-1szn76m-0 cRcVWO i18nString-raclU">Image</div><div class="sc-1szn76m-0 cRcVWO title-RrK9J">Grandmother outside the temple.</div></div></div></div></figure></div></div>
<p data-aid="159163230" id="p47">Also, where your circumstances permit, please consider the blessing of owning your own temple clothes.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note23" data-scroll-id="note23"><sup class="marker" data-value="23"></sup></a> A grandmother from a humble family said of anything in the world, what she most wanted were her own temple clothes. Her grandson said, “Grandma whispered, ‘I will serve in my own temple clothes, and after <span class="page-break" data-page="44"></span>I die, I will be buried in them.’” And when the time came, she was.</p>
<p data-aid="159163237" id="p48">As President Russell M. Nelson teaches, “<em>Everything</em> we believe and <em>every</em> promise God has made to His covenant people come together in the temple.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/25gong?lang=eng#note24" data-scroll-id="note24"><sup class="marker" data-value="24"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159163240" id="p49">In time and eternity, the purpose of Creation and the nature of God Himself are to bring all things together for our good.</p>
<p data-aid="159163248" id="p50">This is the Lord’s eternal purpose. It is His eternal perspective. It is His eternal promise.</p>
<p data-aid="159163254" id="p51">When life is cluttered and purpose isn’t clear, when you want to live better but don’t know how, please come to God our Father and Jesus Christ. Trust They live, love you, and want all things for your good. I testify They do, infinitely and eternally, in the sacred and holy name of Jesus Christ, amen.</p>
</div>
<footer class="notes">
<p class="title" data-aid="159163261" id="note_title1">Notes</p>
<ol class="decimal" data-type="marker" start="1">
<li data-marker="1." id="note1" data-full-marker="1.">

</li>
<li data-marker="2." id="note2" data-full-marker="2.">
<p data-aid="159163274" id="note2_p1"><a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/nt/rom/8?lang=eng&id=p28#p28">Romans 8:28</a>.</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="3." id="note3" data-full-marker="3.">
<p data-aid="159163280" id="note3_p1"><a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/dc-testament/dc/90?lang=eng&id=p24#p24">Doctrine and Covenants 90:24</a>. The popular phrase “It’s all good” often implies things are OK and in order, without necessarily meaning they are actually for our good.</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="4." id="note4" data-full-marker="4.">

</li>
<li data-marker="5." id="note5" data-full-marker="5.">

</li>
<li data-marker="6." id="note6" data-full-marker="6.">
<p data-aid="159163295" id="note6_p1">See <a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/bofm/2-ne/9?lang=eng&id=p10-p12#p10">2 Nephi 9:10–12</a>. God respects moral agency, sometimes allowing even the unrighteous acts of others to affect us. But as we willingly seek to do all we can, Jesus Christ’s grace and His enabling and atoning power can cleanse, heal, bind up, reconcile us with ourselves and each other, on both sides of the veil.</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="7." id="note7" data-full-marker="7.">
<p data-aid="159163304" id="note7_p1">See <a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/bofm/moro/7?lang=eng&id=p6,10-p12#p6">Moroni 7:6, 10–12</a>. Professor Terry Warner writes perceptively on this topic.</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="8." id="note8" data-full-marker="8.">
<p data-aid="159163306" id="note8_p1">See <a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/nt/rom/3?lang=eng&id=p10#p10">Romans 3:10</a>; <a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/bofm/moro/10?lang=eng&id=p25#p25">Moroni 10:25</a>.</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="9." id="note9" data-full-marker="9.">
<p data-aid="159163313" id="note9_p1">See <a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/bofm/moro/10?lang=eng&id=p32#p32">Moroni 10:32</a>.</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="10." id="note10" data-full-marker="10.">
<p data-aid="159163317" id="note10_p1">See <a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/dc-testament/dc/122?lang=eng&id=p4,7#p4">Doctrine and Covenants 122:4, 7</a>.</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="11." id="note11" data-full-marker="11.">
<p data-aid="159163322" id="note11_p1">We learn by experiences we would never choose. Sometimes bearing burdens with the Lord’s help can increase our capacity to bear those burdens; <a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/bofm/mosiah/24?lang=eng&id=p10-p15#p10">Mosiah 24:10–15</a> illustrates the Lord’s promise to “visit my people in their afflictions” and to “strengthen them that they could bear up their burdens.” <a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/bofm/alma/33?lang=eng&id=p23#p23">Alma 33:23</a> teaches that our “burdens may be light, through the joy of his Son.” <a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/bofm/mosiah/18?lang=eng&id=p8#p8">Mosiah 18:8</a> reminds us that when we are “willing to bear one another’s burdens … they may be light.”</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="12." id="note12" data-full-marker="12.">
<p data-aid="159163327" id="note12_p1">The prophet Isaiah speaks of the Messiah: “The Spirit of the Lord God is upon me; because the Lord hath anointed me to preach good tidings unto the meek; he hath sent me to bind up the brokenhearted, … to comfort all that mourn; to appoint unto them that mourn in Zion, to give unto them beauty for ashes, the oil of joy for mourning, the garment of praise for the spirit of heaviness” (<a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/ot/isa/61?lang=eng&id=p1-p3#p1">Isaiah 61:1–3</a>). Likewise, the psalmist offers the Lord’s promised perspective: “Weeping may endure for a night, but joy cometh in the morning” (<a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/ot/ps/30?lang=eng&id=p5#p5">Psalm 30:5</a>). This includes the glorious promises for the righteous on the morning of the First Resurrection.</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="13." id="note13" data-full-marker="13.">
<p data-aid="159163334" id="note13_p1"><a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/dc-testament/dc/122?lang=eng&id=p4#p4">Doctrine and Covenants 122:4</a>. Believing trials may be for what is in eternity a “small moment” does not mean to downplay or make less trying or challenging the agonizing pain or suffering we may experience day after day in this life, the unbearable sleepless nights, or the excruciating uncertainties of each new day. Perhaps the promise of being able to look back and see our mortal suffering in light of God’s compassion and eternal view adds some perspective to our understanding of mortality and our hope to endure with faith and trust in Him to the end. Also, when we have eyes to see, there is often good in the now; we need not necessarily wait for a future time to see good.</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="14." id="note14" data-full-marker="14.">
<p data-aid="159163339" id="note14_p1">See <a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/bofm/2-ne/2?lang=eng&id=p2#p2">2 Nephi 2:2</a>.</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="15." id="note15" data-full-marker="15.">
<p data-aid="159163346" id="note15_p1">See <a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/nt/matt/7?lang=eng&id=p9-p10#p9">Matthew 7:9–10</a>. Letting God prevail in our lives is not passively to accept whatever comes. It is actively to believe that Heavenly Father and our Savior, Jesus Christ, want only and always what is best for us. When tragedy strikes, we can ask with faith, not “Why me?” but “What can I learn?” And we can mourn with broken hearts and contrite spirits, knowing, in His time and way, compensating blessings and opportunities will come.</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="16." id="note16" data-full-marker="16.">
<p data-aid="159163352" id="note16_p1">We have covenanted to mourn with those who mourn and comfort those who stand in need of comfort (see <a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/bofm/mosiah/18?lang=eng&id=p9#p9">Mosiah 18:9</a>).</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="17." id="note17" data-full-marker="17.">
<p data-aid="159163359" id="note17_p1"><a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/ot/job/1?lang=eng&id=p21#p21">Job 1:21</a>.</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="18." id="note18" data-full-marker="18.">
<p data-aid="159163366" id="note18_p1">See <a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/dc-testament/dc/115?lang=eng&id=p6#p6">Doctrine and Covenants 115:6</a>.</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="19." id="note19" data-full-marker="19.">
<p data-aid="159163374" id="note19_p1">Faith in the face of difficulty is the opposite of the existential anguish and despair the Book of Mormon describes of those who “curse God, and wish to die” but who “nevertheless … would struggle with the sword for their lives” (<a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/bofm/morm/2?lang=eng&id=p14#p14">Mormon 2:14</a>).</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="20." id="note20" data-full-marker="20.">
<p data-aid="159163381" id="note20_p1">“Be Still, My Soul,” <cite>Hymns</cite>, no. 124.</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="21." id="note21" data-full-marker="21.">
<p data-aid="159163388" id="note21_p1">“Come, Come, Ye Saints,” <cite>Hymns</cite>, no. 30. Consider also:</p>
<div class="poetry">
<div class="stanza">
<p class="line" data-aid="159163403" id="note21_p2">How great the wisdom and the love. …</p>
<p class="line" data-aid="159163412" id="note21_p3">Redemption’s grand design,</p>
<p class="line" data-aid="159163420" id="note21_p4">Where justice, love, and mercy meet</p>
<p class="line" data-aid="159163429" id="note21_p5">In harmony divine!</p>
<p class="line" data-aid="159163438" id="note21_p7">(“How Great the Wisdom and the Love,” <cite>Hymns</cite>, no. 195.)</p>
</div>
</div>
<p data-aid="159163446" id="note21_p6">Amid life’s uncertainties, we know redemption’s grand design will bring justice, love, and mercy together for our good.</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="22." id="note22" data-full-marker="22.">
<p data-aid="159163456" id="note22_p1">See <a class="scripture-ref" href="/study/scriptures/ot/obad/1?lang=eng&id=p21#p21">Obadiah 1:21</a>. The Prophet Joseph Smith taught: “How are they [the Latter-day Saints] to become saviors on Mount Zion? By building their temples, erecting their baptismal fonts, and going forth and receiving all the ordinances … in behalf of all their progenitors who are dead” (<cite><a class="cross-ref" href="/study/manual/teachings-joseph-smith/chapter-41?lang=eng&id=p18#p18">Teachings of Presidents of the Church: Joseph Smith</a></cite> [2007], 473).</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="23." id="note23" data-full-marker="23.">
<p data-aid="159163464" id="note23_p1">Members attending the temple for the first time can purchase temple clothes at a significant discount.</p>
</li>
<li data-marker="24." id="note24" data-full-marker="24.">
